articles.title: Use Parcel Macros in Other Bundlers with unplugin-parcel-macros
articles.description: Macros, as implemented in Parcel (and Bun!), are JS functions that run at build time whose results are inlined into a bundle in place of the original call. You can now use this feature with webpack, Vite, Rollup, esbuild, etc. Here's a quick example of how handy this can be.
articles.author: Devon Govett

articles.title: Speedometer 3.0: The Best Way Yet to Measure Browser Performance
articles.description: Speedometer has been around since 2014, but this new release is the first with a full collaborative approach involving each major browser engine (Blink, Gecko, WebKit). You can run the test yourself here.
articles.author: Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla

articles.title: WinterJS 1.0: A Fast WinterCG and WASM-Compatible JS Runtime
articles.description: WinterJS initially pitched itself as a Rust and SpiderMonkey-powered ‚ÄòService Workers server‚Äô but now simply boasts being the fastest WinterCG-compatible JavaScript web server full stop. The ability to run JITed JS workloads entirely under WebAssembly is next on their radar.
articles.author: Wasmer

articles.title: Comparing JavaScript Frameworks: Templates
articles.description: A thorough comparison of the template languages used by React, Vue, Angular and Svelte. Interesting analysis and this looks set to turn into a great series.
articles.author: Maarten Hus

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Setting up an Express.js App with TypeScript in 2024
articles.description: This hour-long video isn't about building an entire app, but getting everything set up and working in a clear, easy to follow way, including a variety of modern DX niceties.
articles.author: Anson the Developer

articles.title: Make Your TypeScript Functions More Reusable with Generics
articles.description: Matt kicks this off with a challenge for you to consider, before showing how to make a function more flexible and type-safe by using type parameters instead of any.
articles.author: Matt Pocock

articles.title: Shiki 1.0: A Powerful Syntax Highlighter
articles.description: A few months ago, we linked to Shikiji, a fork of Shiki that was created to push the project forward. Happily, the creators of both libraries decided to join forces and Shiki 1.0 was born. It‚Äôs a syntax highlighter based on TextMate grammar and themes, the same engine as used by VS Code. The docs are good.
articles.author: Pine Wu, Anthony Fu

articles.title: Rolldown: A Rust-Powered Bundler for JavaScript
articles.description: A new entry to an increasingly crowded market, but they explain why they‚Äôre building it here ‚Äì it‚Äôs intended to underpin a future bundler to be used in Vite, rather than esbuild and Rollup. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Rolldown

articles.title: Storybook 8 Released
articles.description: The popular front-end component workshop introduces built-in visual testing, support for React Server Components, up to 50% faster start times, Vite 5 support, and upgraded Vue and React control auto-generation. There‚Äôs also ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a launch video to enjoy.
articles.author: Michael Shilman (Storybook)

articles.title: The Playwright Test Generator
articles.description: I don't know why I‚Äôve not linked this before, as it‚Äôs so useful. Playwright isn‚Äôt just a library for controlling browsers from JavaScript, but also includes a tool for generating tests and page navigation code from your own interactions. Hit record, do stuff, and code is written.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: TinyBase 4.7: A Reactive Data Store for Local-First Apps
articles.description: If you want a bit more database-esque structure around the management of state in your apps, this is worth a try. The demos show it off well. v4.7 adds support for Turso‚Äôs LibSQL (a fork of SQLite).
articles.author: James Pearce et al.

articles.title: ‚åòK 1.0: A Composable, Unstyled 'Command Menu' for React Apps
articles.description: The home page includes some neat examples in a variety of styles. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Paco Coursey

articles.title: webtoon/PSD: Zero-Dependency PSD Parser for Browsers and Node
articles.description: PSD (Photoshop Document) is the format used by Photoshop and this library lets you dig into metadata and pixels on each image layer.
articles.author: webtoon inc

articles.description: Last week we linked to JSR, Deno's attempt at a new JavaScript registry. If that post was too much to digest, they now have ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a 6-minute video introduction covering the key motivations and features.
The Astro folks have unveiled Astro DB, a fully managed SQL database designed exclusively for Astro.
üìä Benchmarking Node vs LLRT/QuickJS.
f(x) is a fantastic terminal-based JSON viewer app (written in Go, but it can integrate with JS functions) ‚Äì its latest version supports YAML too.
Biome 1.6 ‚Äì The toolchain gets partial support for Astro, Svelte & Vue files.
D3.js 7.9 ‚Äì Popular data visualization library. They launched a fantastic new homepage several months ago too, if you haven't checked in for a while.
React Native Skia 1.0 ‚Äì Complete with ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a launch video.
Node.js v21.7.1, Cypress 13.7, Angular 17.3, Ember 5.7

articles.title: Announcing Speedometer 3.0: A Shared Browser Benchmark for Web Application Responsiveness
articles.description: Speedometer has been around since 2014, but this new 3.0 release is the first with a new cross-industry collaborative approach that's supported by each major browser engine (Blink, Gecko, WebKit). Version 3 adds many new tests, performance wins, and improvements. The WebKit team call it the ‚Äúbest way yet to measure browser performance‚Äù.
articles.author: Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla

articles.title: Interaction to Next Paint is Now Officially a Core Web Vital
articles.description: It has now replaced First Input Delay. Here‚Äôs a quick recap of what‚Äôs now changed along with some resources to help you find and fix INP issues.
articles.author: Rick Viscomi (Google)

articles.title: The Quiet, Pervasive Devaluation of Frontend
articles.description: Considered introspection here on the discernment of the frontend trade as a whole: ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm seeing a widespread diminishment of the practice of frontend. [..] I notice its importance minimized, and its challenges trivialized.‚Äù
articles.author: Josh Collinsworth

articles.title: Creating Color Palettes with the CSS color-mix() Function
articles.description: This article serves as a thorough explainer on how best to use new CSS color-mix() functions to create variations in color palettes.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: Streaming HTML Out of Order Without JavaScript
articles.description: An interesting, yet short and sweet, demo of a browser feature that enables a technique you may not have imagined possible without JavaScript, though support is still very fresh in Firefox.
articles.author: Chris Haynes

articles.title: CSS Variable Groups
articles.description: A proposed way to define multiple properties under the same namespace and pass the entire group around, addressing several pain points around design tokens, design systems, and integrating third-party components. Lea notes that it has been shared with the CSS Working Group.
articles.author: Lea Verou

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†The Importance of Web Performance to Information Equity
articles.description: A 20-minute talk on the vital role of ensuring equal access to web information and services for those with expensive data, slower devices, or both.
articles.author: Bas Schouten

articles.title: Improvements to the Speculation Rules API
articles.description: A look over the latest updates to the experimental Speculation Rules API ‚Äî designed to improve performance for future navigations. These include document rules, eagerness setting, limits, and platform support.
articles.author: Barry Pollard (Chrome for Developers)

articles.title: 'Jakob Has Jumped the Shark'?
articles.description: It‚Äôs fair to say Jakob Nielsen‚Äôs latest rumination on generative UI has caused plenty of chatter, as this collection of responses shows.
articles.author: Adrian Roselli

articles.title: A Practical Guide To Designing for Colorblind People
articles.description: Some practical accessibility guidelines and resources to ensure more inclusive design for those with color vision deficiency.
articles.author: Vitaly Friedman

articles.title: Capo.js: A Five Minute Web Performance Boost?
articles.description: Dave quips that this tool can offer a five minute web performance win that‚Äôs ‚Äúsure to get you a promotion‚Äù üòâ. The tool in question? It‚Äôs Capo.js ‚Äî designed to help you get the elements in your <head> in order, hopefully resulting in perf gains.
articles.author: Dave Rupert

articles.title: This is WCAG: A Free Resource to Help You Build Inclusive Web Experiences
articles.description: Includes 80+ tests that you can filter by conformance level and different accessibility categories. Also offers brief explanations so you can better understand the meaning of each accessibility criterion.
articles.author: canaxess

articles.title: Expressive Code: An Engine for Presenting Source Code on the Web
articles.description: Sort of like a syntax highlighter on steroids, this gives you some extra flexibility, allowing customizations like editor/terminal frames, text/line markers, collapsible sections, and more.
articles.author: Expressive Code

articles.title: Finder 3.2: CSS Selector Generator
articles.description: Given an element, it produces the shortest possible selector that reaches (solely) that element.
articles.author: Anton Medvedev
